title: 111_s2911
content: The "Common Sense Budgeting Act" is also known as the Act. It amends Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 by adding discretionary spending limits. The "Common Sense Budgeting Act" adds discretionary spending limits to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974, restricting the House and Senate from considering bills that exceed set limits for defense and nondefense budget authority for fiscal years 2010-2012. The "Common Sense Budgeting Act" sets budget authority limits for defense and nondefense spending for fiscal years 2010-2014, with specific amounts allocated for each year. Waivers in the Senate require a two-thirds majority vote. The "Common Sense Budgeting Act" establishes budget authority limits for defense and nondefense spending for fiscal years 2010-2014. Appeals in the Senate regarding this section are limited to 1 hour and require a two-thirds majority vote to sustain. Title II of the "Common Sense Budgeting Act" introduces a pay-as-you-go point of order in the Senate under Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. Title II of the "Common Sense Budgeting Act" introduces a point of order in the Senate that restricts consideration of direct spending or revenue legislation that would increase the on-budget deficit for specific time periods. Direct spending legislation is defined as any bill, joint resolution, amendment, motion, or conference report affecting direct spending as defined by the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985, excluding certain provisions like concurrent resolutions on the budget. The Budget Enforcement Act of 1990 requires estimates to use the baseline surplus or deficit from the most recent budget resolution and assume the continuation of expiring programs and revenue reductions. The Budget Enforcement Act of 1990 requires a supermajority vote in the Senate to waive or appeal decisions related to taxes and customs duties.
